Question 1: A 35-year-old female patient of asian ethnicity with a BMI of 34 kg/m² has decided to seek 
surgical options to reduce her weight. She has multiple comorbidities. Which of the following 
would make her unsuitable for bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation:
Severe depression would make her unsuitable for bariatric surgery. The patient should be 
psychologically stable before undergoing bariatric surgery. Psychological instability makes the patient incapable of understanding the implications of the 
procedure. It becomes difficult for the patient to understand the lifestyle changes necessary for 
optimal outcomes. 461

specific for Asian and Indian populations are as follows: The criteria for Asian and Indian patients has been modified by reducing the BMI by 2.5 points.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery?

options.a: Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy

questions.explanation:
Failure to lose weight by an obese patient despite psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and lifestyle 
modifications is an indication for metabolic surgery. Potential contraindications to metabolic and bariatric surgery include: • Severe medical disease making anesthesia or surgery prohibitively risky (American Society of 
Anesthesiologists class IV) • Mentally incompetent to understand the procedure • Inability or unwillingness to change lifestyle postoperatively • Drug, alcohol, or other addiction (including smoking) • Active problem of bulimia or other eating disorder • Psychological instability (schizophrenia, severe depression) • Unsupportive home environment 462 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 3: For a patient being considered for bariatric surgery, which of the following will you not 
include when calculating the Obesity Surgery-Mortality risk score (OS-MRS score)?
questions.explanation:
Type-2 Diabetes mellitus (DM) is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score 
(OS-MRS). Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) and Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) 
are used to discuss with patients the likely prognosis without surgery, and the risk of 
complications. Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS): Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is considered a risk factor, as in any other surgery. However, it is not

questions.question:
Question 4: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to 
undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a 457 
Sold by @itachibot low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is 
found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Psychological re-evaluation is necessary to address the underlying psychological blocks in a 
patient who is unable to comply with the diet. Morbidly obese individuals, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make 
surgery impossible. Liver shrinkage diet helps reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for 
the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure. Liver shrinkage diet: • Low-carbohydrate, low-fat and moderate protein diet • Started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery 463 
Sold by @itachibot The ability to comply with the diet and lose weight suggests that the patient is willing to make an 
effort to adopt lifestyle modifications. Failure to do so must arouse suspicion of important 
underlying psychological blocks, which need addressing.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a reversible bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation:
Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to be 
reversible bariatric surgeries. It is because the gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weight 
loss or metabolic benefit is achieved. 464 
Sold by @itachibot An inflatable band is placed just below the GE junction  A small virtual stomach pouch is created  Reduces hunger (probably vagally mediated)  Reduced consumption of food  Weight loss Complications of LAGB include: • Prolapse / Slippage (most common) • Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery), 
managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

questions.question: Question 7: In recent years, what is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation:
Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery, in recent years. A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature  Restriction of stomach capacity  465 
Sold by @itachibot Early satiety  Reduced consumption of food  Weight loss Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy: • Less challenging procedure • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping) • No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding) • Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) Complications of sleeve gastrectomy: • Bleed from the staple line • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

questions.question:
Question 8: 458 
Sold by @itachibot A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m² underwent laparoscopic sleeve 
gastrectomy (LSG). On the second postoperative day, she developed fever, tachycardia, and 
blood reports show leucocytosis. What is the next best step in her management?

options.a: Send blood for culture and sensitivity
options.b: USG abdomen to locate the septic focus

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient of 
LSG should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in the 
management of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT. Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to the 
angle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually due 
to ischemia and high intragastric pressure. Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequate 
drainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral. Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can be 
done either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operative 
procedures. Note: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for an anastomotic leak. Treatment with 
continuous positive airway pressure might reduce this risk.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following statements is true regarding Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in bariatric 
surgery?

options.a: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature.
options.b: Biliary limb is 100-150 cm in length
options.c: It is a purely restrictive type of procedure.

questions.explanation:
Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. 466 
Sold by @itachibot A small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature  Create a shorter biliary limb of 30 - 50 cm (duodenum); Create a longer Roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum)  Bowel continuity is restored by a Y - jejunojejunostomy  Restrictive + Malabsorptive mechanism  Weight loss Note: Biliary limb is usually kept short (30-50 cm) in order to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the 
abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months 
ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below. 
Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient? 459 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in 
the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, 
Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small 
bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel 
obstruction. In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, 
space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing 
the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open 
surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from 467 
Sold by @itachibot herniating. Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly 
reduces the risk of internal hernia. Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: • Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12 • Anastomosis site leak • Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy • Dumping syndrome • Marginal ulcers • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak. Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion. Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with 
postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient who previously underwent biliopancreatic diversion surgery has been having 
excessive malabsorption and is now being planned for a revisional procedure to increase the 
length of the common channel. What is the usual length of the common channel?
questions.explanation:
The usual length of the common channel in biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) is 50 cm (0.5 m). Revisions increase common channel by up to 150 cm. The length of the common channel plays a significant role in the amount of weight loss achieved 
with BPD procedure. A shorter common channel implies a greater length of the bypassed small 
bowel. This induces more malabsorption and thereby greater weight loss. Distal hemigastrectomy is performed to create a residual gastric pouch  468 
Sold by @itachibot Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve  Gastroileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and residual 
gastric pouch  Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum  A common channel of 50 cm is established  Malabsorption  Weight loss Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of 
gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts. Complications of biliopancreatic diversion surgery: • Anastomosis site leak • Nutritional deficiencies: Iron; folate; vitamins A, D, K, and B12 • Marginal ulcers • Bleeding • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery), 
managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is not a surgical step that will be done during a duodenal switch 
procedure?
questions.explanation:
In duodenal switch (DS) surgery, gastroduodenostomy is not performed. 469 
Sold by @itachibot Sleeve gastrectomy is performed  Duodenum is divided 2 cm beyond the pylorus; Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve  Duodenoileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and duodenum  Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum  A common channel of 100 cm is established  Malabsorption  Weight loss Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of 
gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts. Complications of duodenal switch surgery: • Anastomosis site leak and bleeding • Nutritional deficiencies - Iron, folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12 • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery) - 
managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH In comparison to BPD, the 
incidence of marginal ulcers is negligible 470 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary embolism is the most common cause of death in patients of bariatric surgery. Pathogenesis: Obesity  Increased levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1  Blocks conversion of plasminogen to plasmin  Decreased fibrinolytic activity  Hypercoagulable state  Increased risk for VTE Morbidly obese patients are physically inactive. Restricted mobility post-surgery potentiates this 
risk of developing deep vein thrombosis.
